newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada govt pressured to help Canadian Air.
newsitem.headline: Canada govt pressured to help Canadian Air.

text.p: Pressure mounted on Canada's federal government on Wednesday to announce financial aid for troubled Canadian Airlines Corp as a deadline loomed for Canada's second biggest carrier to conclude a rescue plan.

Two of the biggest unions remained defiant in their opposition to company and government demands for wage concessions. Their opposition has blocked a restructuring plan agreed to by four unions and the company.
That plan would involve average wage cuts of about five percent and C$35 million in assistance from Ottawa and the provinces of Alberta and British Columbia, officials said.
Canadian would save a total of C$70 million.
The company has set a deadline of midnight Wednesday for agreement on the restructuring plan.

Canadian president Kevin Benson told reporters that the deadline was firm and his focus today would be convincing the two holdout unions and federal government to agree to the restructuring. "We have the best plan we can get. It's right here...waiting and ready to happen," he said.
The Canadian Union of Public Employees and the Canadian Auto Workers, who represent 6,300 of Canadian's 16,400 workers, have refused to consider wage concessions.
They are calling for the federal government to help rescue the airline and re-regulate the industry.

Federal Transport Minister David Anderson has been in Vancouver all week in a bid to resolve the crisis, but he has refused to commit to any assistance until all the airline's unions agreed to wage cuts.

"We need you to say you will put money into this airline and show some leadership," CUPE president Judy Darcy urged Ottawa in a speech to a labor convention in Vancouver on Wednesday. Added CAW president Buzz Hargrove: "The government has to step in."
They said creditors, including major lender Royal Bank of Canada and AMR Corp, parent of American Airlines and 33 percent owner of Canadian, must make sacrifices.

The International Association of Machinists, which has agreed to the restructuring plan, said swift help from Ottawa was vital to get the rescue operation off the ground. "One of the main players still has not come to the plate -- the federal government," said IAM president Dave Ritchie.
Alberta Premier Ralph Klein agreed Tuesday to measures including fuel tax breaks and an easing of loan terms. British Columbia Premier Glen Clark also expressed willingness to help.
Clark was in Dallas on Wednesday to meet with AMR officials, union officials said.

Canadian has been seeking a C$48 million reduction in the fees it pays to AMR and a Vancouver television station reported that Clark would also explore AMR's interest in raising its stake in Canadian. The federal government has expressed reservations about that idea.
